description.plain:
Christopher Rios (November 10, 1971 – February 7, 2000), also known as Big Pun (short for Big Punisher), was a Puerto Rican rapper who emerged from the underground rap scene in The Bronx in the late 1990s. Pun was discovered by friend Fat Joe and was a part of his Terror Squad label and collective. On February 7, 2000, he passed away due to a heart attack and respiratory failure.

Big Pun grew up in New York City’s South Bronx and by all accounts from Pun’s family, his early years were very difficult, including witnessing his mother’s drug abuse, his father’s death, and a stepfather who was very hard on him. Pun’s lyrics are notable for technical efficiency, having minimal pauses to take a breath, heavy use of alliteration as well as internal and multi-syllabic rhyming schemes. He is widely regarded as one of the most technical rappers of all time.

Big Pun’s youngest child and only son, Christopher Rios, Jr, followed in his father’s footsteps and also has a career rapping as Chris Rivers.

songs.full_title: Twinz (Deep Cover '98) by Big Pun (Ft. Fat Joe)
songs.title: Twinz (Deep Cover ’98)

description.plain:
Big Pun and Fat Joe cover Dr. Dre and Snoop Doggy Dogg’s 1992 track “Deep Cover.” Snoop also makes a cameo in the music video.

Fat Joe said the following about the friendly competition between himself and Pun during an interview with XXL magazine in 2004:

At the time, I really thought I was getting over on Pun. When we [were] writing, I thought I had him. I was coming with ‘Creep with me, as I cruise in my Beemer…’ I thought I was freaking it! But that was not the case. I still don’t know what his shit means. I can still hear Pun saying, ‘You’re limited, Joe.’

songs.full_title: Still Not a Player by Big Pun (Ft. Joe)
songs.title: Still Not a Player

description.plain:
“Still Not a Player” was released as Big Pun’s second single and was a remix of his debut single “I’m Not a Player” merged with the chorus from R&B singer Joe’s hit single “Don’t Wanna Be a Player”. The single became the biggest hit of Pun’s career, peaking at #6 on the Billboard Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart and #24 on the Billboard Hot 100.

During an interview with XXL magazine in 2004, Joe talked about the process of making the song:


Pun came to me with the idea to merge the two songs together–my original song, ‘Don’t Wanna Be a Player,’ and his ‘Still Not a Player.’ We [were] just merging the two records together.

He was there when I did my part. Pun was cool. Just real relaxed, very focused, a very focused person. He knew exactly what he wanted. He knew automatically that the song was gonna be a smash. He felt it from the door, when he brought me into int. Let’s make magic happen. It was fun–a lot of fun. We kind of made history together. The record just continued to be a big record everywhere it went.


“Still Not a Player” sampled the intro from “A Little Bit Of Love” by Brenda Russell.

songs.full_title: Beware by Big Pun
songs.title: Beware

description.plain:
Over an ominous-sounding sample from Henry Mancini’s “Theme for the Losers” mixed with a vocal sample from Prodigy’s verse on the first version of Mobb Deep’s “Shook Ones,” Big Pun enters the rap arena issuing a “fair warning” to all challengers that he is ready to punish the competition.

Producer JuJu from The Beatnuts talked about the production of the track in a 2004 interview with XXL magazine:

Pun gave me an idea. He told me, ‘I need that dirty, grimy shit. You gotta give me a track that’s gonna let niggas know how I’m coming.’ And I was like, ‘That’s what I’m good at. Some niggas do dance records. I do the grimy, dirty shit.’ So I went into the lab, did a couple of beats. I came back, let him hear some stuff and he was like, ‘This is it, man.’ [It had a Mobb Deep sample in the beginning] ‘I gave you fair warning: Beware.’

Fat Joe also talked about his part on the track:

This is one of my favorite tracks ever by Pun, a greater introduction couldn’t be done. So I got on the back of it and started talking shit, basically trying to tell niggas I’m not alone no more. I found a partner who sees my same point of view, and he’s nasty. Deal with that. Y'all got a problem, let me know. Muthafuckas was like, ‘Not only do we gotta deal with Fat Joe, now we gotta deal with the nicest nigga in the universe.’

annotatable.title: Beware

body.plain:
Over an ominous-sounding sample from Henry Mancini’s “Theme for the Losers” mixed with a vocal sample from Prodigy’s verse on the first version of Mobb Deep’s “Shook Ones,” Big Pun enters the rap arena issuing a “fair warning” to all challengers that he is ready to punish the competition.

Producer JuJu from The Beatnuts talked about the production of the track in a 2004 interview with XXL magazine:

Pun gave me an idea. He told me, ‘I need that dirty, grimy shit. You gotta give me a track that’s gonna let niggas know how I’m coming.’ And I was like, ‘That’s what I’m good at. Some niggas do dance records. I do the grimy, dirty shit.’ So I went into the lab, did a couple of beats. I came back, let him hear some stuff and he was like, ‘This is it, man.’ [It had a Mobb Deep sample in the beginning] ‘I gave you fair warning: Beware.’

Fat Joe also talked about his part on the track:

This is one of my favorite tracks ever by Pun, a greater introduction couldn’t be done. So I got on the back of it and started talking shit, basically trying to tell niggas I’m not alone no more. I found a partner who sees my same point of view, and he’s nasty. Deal with that. Y'all got a problem, let me know. Muthafuckas was like, ‘Not only do we gotta deal with Fat Joe, now we gotta deal with the nicest nigga in the universe.’

songs.full_title: It's So Hard by Big Pun (Ft. Donell Jones)
songs.title: It’s So Hard

description.plain:
Album: Yeeeah Baby
Year: 2000
Charts: #75 (Billboard Hot 100)

‘It’s So Hard’ is the debut single from Big Pun’s second studio-album, and features guest vocals from R&B singer, Donnell Jones. The track was released two-months after his death, and because of this it was decided that the video would become a tribute to him.

The video filmed in New York City features various members of the Hip-Hop community, and also includes family members such as his wife and three children. It also features an unknown DJ Khaled.

The song is Pun describing how hard it is to be him. He describes people hating on him, attempts  to take his wife, but also what it’s like in New York City; “enemies spit at you, best friends kidnap you/ trust no-one” He also states mentions people coming out of the wood-works now he is becoming more famous, an example lyric is him asking “I know you from where? Elementary School? I don’t know you man!”

In integral part of the beat is a sample of the 1975 song ‘En Un Rincon Del Alma’ by Danny Rivera. The sample begins at 00:32 and is heard throughout.

songs.full_title: You Ain't a Killer by Big Pun
songs.title: You Ain’t a Killer

description.plain:
Big Pun tests the gangsta of so-called gangstas from East to West over a Younglord track that mixes together R&B samples from Michael Jackson’s “With a Child’s Heart” and Kool & the Gang’s “Summer Madness.” Younglord spoke to XXL magazine about the track in 2004:


It’s interesting how that whole thing happened. Once I finished the beat–that was ‘96–I was doing a whole bunch of songs for The LOX–they [were] signed to Bad Boy but weren’t out yet. So I was one of the people demoing songs on them. And Joe and them were in the studio and I hustled my way into getting a meeting with them. He was like, 'Yeah, I’m working on this new artist.’ He brought Pun over to my house and they listened to maybe about 20 beats and that was the last beat I played.

It was big. I was 18. I was still in high school when we recorded it. […] When it came out, I had just started college [at Seton Hall]. It was crazy to be in the dorm and people were playing my joint.

songs.full_title: Super Lyrical by Big Pun (Ft. Black Thought)
songs.title: Super Lyrical

description.plain:
Lyrical heavyweights Big Pun and Black Thought collaborate over a Rockwilder track that utilizes vocal samples from Canibus (“It’s Logic”) and The Notorious B.I.G. (“One More Chance [Remix]”), with a clever use of a clip from Rocky IV at the end of the track.

Loud Records A&R Sean Cane spoke with XXL magazine in 2004 about Big Pun’s reason for wanting Black Thought to be featured on “Super Lyrical”:

Pun wanted to use Black Thought on there because everybody else was sleeping on him. He was like, ‘Yo, Black Thought is mad lyrical. Y'all don’t realize that. Everybody’s sleeping on him. Watch, I'ma put him on here so niggas see how lyrical he is.’

Fat Joe added:

Pun was like, ‘Yo, I wanna fuck with him.’ And at first, I thought Black Thought kinda got in his ass. But Pun’ll set a nigga up–let you rhyme equal to him, then come out here and fuck you up.

songs.full_title: I'm Not A Player by Big Pun
songs.title: I’m Not A Player

description.plain:
“I’m Not a Player” was released in 1997 as the lead single to Big Pun’s debut album Capital Punishment. The B-side of the single was “Wishful Thinking” featuring Fat Joe, Kool G. Rap, and B-Real from Cypress Hill. “I’m Not a Player” utilizes a sample from “Darlin' Darlin' Baby (Sweet Tender Love)” by The O'Jays. The O'Jays make a cameo in the music video as the band performing at the club where Pun is.

The song was later remixed as “Still Not a Player” featuring Joe and released as the second single from Capital Punishment.

Producer Minnesota talked about how the track came together during an interview with XXL magazine in 2004:


When I was younger, I used to go to the family parties in the projects on Webster [Avenue in the Bronx]. When I was a little kid they used to play the O'Jays record ‘Darlin’ Darlin' Baby.‘ I had found a jazz version of the record so I combined it with the original O'Jays joint. I actually had SWV in mind, to get the beat to them. But Big Pun heard it and he loved it.

I played the track for him and he had a vision for it. I didn’t disagree with him; the only thing I had disagreed with him about is when we got to [the chorus of the radio version, where he said], ‘Crush a lot.’ I was like, ‘Crush a lot? Find another word.’ He was like, ‘There’s no other word, watch.’


Fat Joe also talked about the track:

I argued with Pun to the day that he died that I gave him that line: ‘I’m not a player, I just fuck a lot.’ We [were] watching the videos in the house, they had the shiny suits and was flashing the watches and all that. I was like, ‘We need to make a record like: 'I ain’t a player, I just fuck a lot.’ He was like, ‘Word! That’s hot!’ Sat down right there and started writing it. Being that was his biggest record ever, he fought with me about it forever.

songs.full_title: The Dream Shatterer by Big Pun
songs.title: The Dream Shatterer

description.plain:
Over a driving beat produced by Latino producer Domingo, Big Pun delivers one of his best recorded verses on his debut album Capital Punishment, in a very good example of braggadocio rap, all the while likening himself to NBA superstar Michael Jordan and crooner Nat King Cole.

The first verse was previously delivered on what has been described as “The Legendary Cypher,” a roundtable discussion between Big Pun, Canibus, Mic Geronimo, Mos Def, DMX, and John Forté. It can be seen around 5:05 on this video.

Producer Domingo spoke to XXL magazine in 2004 about how the track came together:


When I was in the middle of doing [Fat Joe’s] Jealous Ones Envy album [in 1995], Pun was always coming to the studio. Pun asked me for a beat tape, because CDs were not even in style yet. The beat for ‘Dream Shatterer’ was on that tape, and Big Pun always told me, ‘Yo, when I get a deal, it’s on.’ He told me not to sell the beat. A couple of years went down the line. Pun called me one night when he was working on Capital Punishment. He was like, ‘What’s up with that beat that I told you to save?’ I was like, ‘Yeah. I still got it.’

So I went up to the studio, Axis Studios on 54th Street [in Manhattan]. Pun came in the room and played me the original ‘Dream Shatterer,’ which was the Barry White sample. He told me he couldn’t clear the sample because at that time Puffy had the [‘I Dare You’] record out with Black Rob with the same sample. So Pun said, ‘Take the a capella of 'Dream Shatterer’ and let me know if the beat matches it.‘ And to be honest with you, when I went home and threw the beat on and put the vocals to it, it sounded like Pun actually rhymed to the track.


“The Dream Shatterer” samples “Funk & Wagner” by Don ‘Sugarcane’ Harris.

songs.full_title: Capital Punishment by Big Pun (Ft. Prospect)
songs.title: Capital Punishment

description.plain:
The title track of Big Pun’s debut album finds him talking about crime, hustling and the harsh life of the streets which has led to many people facing capital punishment.

Producer Trauma said the following about the track to XXL magazine in 2004:

We he heard the ‘Capital Punishment’ beat, he was like, ‘That’s it, right there.’ See, I’m thinking he’s going to rhyme on some street shit, some shoot-‘em-up or whatever. But he just came with some knowledge shit and I was just blown away.

songs.full_title: Boomerang by Big Pun
songs.title: Boomerang

description.plain:
In this song, Big Pun chronicles his life as a gangster.  First he has it all: he gets tons of women and is balling out of control.  But then his rivals get jealous and send his wife pictures of Pun having sex with some women.  Pun gets pissed off, kills his enemies, and then realizes he has to leave town and go on the run

Pun then laments that he wish that, like a boomerang, he could return to where he came from.  The travails of life in the streets bother him and he wishes that life could be different.

This song samples Alain Goraguer’s soundtrack for the movie Fantastic Planet (Le Planete Sauvage). Specifically the song “Le Bracelet.”

songs.full_title: Punish Me by Big Pun (Ft. Miss Jones)
songs.title: Punish Me

description.plain:
“Punish Me” finds Pun speaking on a relationship gone wrong with an immoral woman. He performed this song in a Season Four episode of singer Brandy’s sitcom Moesha.

https://youtu.be/4n1uaqGIr98

Singer Miss Jones spoke about her involvement in the track during an interview with XXL magazine in 2004:

It was a very warm session. I had been friends with Joey for years, since he was on Relativity Records and I was a receptionist there. I had fun. I stayed there pretty much all night. […] Pun was there and he was very hands-on with all the production. They appreciated the value of a singer. They didn’t just want me humming, sounding stupid and off-key. They appreciated it.

Fat Joe also talked about the inspiration behind this song’s creation:

I said, ‘We need to make a song for the bitches, man.’ He didn’t think to do that before. I told him, ‘Yo, we gotta take Biggie’s place.’

songs.artist_names: Big Pun (Ft. Inspectah Deck & Prodigy of Mobb Deep)
songs.full_title: Tres Leches (Triboro Trilogy) by Big Pun (Ft. Inspectah Deck & Prodigy of Mobb Deep)
songs.title: Tres Leches (Triboro Trilogy)
songs.title_with_featured: Tres Leches (Triboro Trilogy) (Ft. Inspectah Deck & Prodigy of Mobb Deep)

description.plain:
Triboro Trilogy refers to the three boroughs of New York represented on this track: Pun (from the Bronx), Deck (from Staten Island), and Prodigy (representing Queens). Regarding the Spanish translation of the song’s title, Prodigy talked about that in an interview with Complex:

I was locked up with my Spanish homies and they were all talking about Pun. So I was like, ‘Yeah, I’ve got a song with Pun called ‘Tres Leches.’’ And my niggas just started falling out laughing, talking about, ‘That shit is called ‘Three Milks?’ Why you got a song called ‘Three Milks?’’ I didn’t even know that shit was called ‘Three Milks!’ I started thinking about it like, ‘Why the fuck is that shit called ‘Three Milks?’’ That shit was kind of bugged the fuck out. I wish Pun was alive, so I could ask the nigga. I just thought the shit sounded cool. I thought that shit meant ‘Three Boroughs’ or something.

Prodigy also said the following to XXL magazine in 2004:

It was Pun’s idea [for each of us to start our verses the same way]. He was like, ‘Yo, I want you to be like this. This is the concept of it.’ And he basically told me what to do. So I was like, ‘Alright cool, I’ll take it from there.’ He was just like ‘There’s going to be a sample in there, Rakim. And then, 'Remember me?’ The one you got your idea from.‘ He was just like, 'Take it from there. Build off of there.’

Inspectah Deck detailed his involvement in the track:

Pun was in the studio, P was in there and they were working on it ahead of me. […] I was grateful for the opportunity. It’s like, Pun and P?! I ain’t gonna miss that. When I got in there, it was a little pressure. I ain’t gonna front. You got Big Pun in there rhyming. He’s a force. He was just becoming a force. And P had already had his name solidified in the game, as well as myself. But I still had a little bit to prove because I still hadn’t done the solo thing. Just being in that room, they brought the best out of me.

Fat Joe also provided some background information:

Tres leches is a Spanish dessert that me and Pun used to eat–a sweet piece of cake, three different milks. I remember we gave RZA cash for the beat. RZA was like, ‘Yo man, I’m saying, I need a paper bag with some money in it.’ I’m like, ‘Yo dog, you know we get paid by the check.’ He’s like, ‘Yeah, the government, man, the government. I need that cash, man.’

songs.full_title: Glamour Life by Big Pun (Ft. Terror Squad)
songs.title: Glamour Life

description.plain:
The Terror Squad come together to talk about the good life: living like kings with the money, women, cars, and jewelry they acquire from their activities.

Terror Squad member Armageddon talked about the track during an interview with XXL magazine in 2004:

We [were] going to use a different beat, actually. The beat that he used with Wyclef on ‘Caribbean Connection.’ That was going to be the beat. […] Pun has always been the nicest out of everybody. We [were] just following his lead.

Fat Joe added:

It was genius the way he kept flipping the chorus. Pun just steals the whole show.

songs.full_title: You Came Up by Big Pun (Ft. N.O.R.E.)
songs.title: You Came Up

description.plain:
“You Came Up” was released as the third single from Capital Punishment and featured Noreaga, fresh off the success of Capone-N-Noreaga’s 1997 debut album The War Report. The horn-filled Rockwilder production features a sample from the intro of “Don’t Ask Me” by Ramon Morris.

Noreaga talked about the track with XXL magazine in 2004:

We were supposed to do a whole other song. It was supposed to be me and him, like, going back and forth talking about being muthafuckin' young Puerto Ricans trying to go platinum. I was running around so much that I never got the chance to do that. So one day he called me like, ‘Yo, I gotta close the album! You gotta come to the studio.’ So when I got to the studio, this is the first time I had ever said anything that I didn’t completely write. He had the whole hook already. So I said, ‘No problem. I'ma leave your format. But I gotta change it to my way.’

Fat Joe added:

That was a song I wasn’t too crazy about, because of the horns. Bwaaa waa waa [imitates drunken horn sounds]. I thought it was too happy. I don’t know how we made that the single, I don’t know how I let them niggas convince me. We got Nore, who was family, but it was almost like a joke to me–it wasn’t like a real song.

songs.full_title: Fast Money by Big Pun
songs.title: Fast Money

description.plain:
Big Pun goes into storytelling mode in this track about obtaining quick cash. Fat Joe spoke to XXL magazine in 2004 about “Fast Money”:

That was one of the greatest storytelling rhymes in hip-hop, ever. It’s songs like this that make me think Pun don’t get his props. This shit is ripped down to the point of a blind man sees this. So lyrical, to me one of the most lyrical storytelling rhymes ever.

songs.full_title: Leather Face by Big Pun
songs.title: Leather Face

description.plain:
One of the standouts from Yeeeah Baby, the backdrop to Pun’s lyrical massacre utilizes a sample of Bill Conti’s “Redemption” -the theme from Rocky II. The song is also peppered with samples of dialogue from the infamous chainsaw scene from Scarface.

Not only do the frequent dialogue samples come from Scarface, but Pun also uses themes having to do with the nickname Leatherface (antagonist from the Texas Chainsaw Massacre  movies) and his infamous chainsaw.

songs.full_title: How We Roll by Big Pun (Ft. Ashanti)
songs.title: How We Roll

description.plain: “How We Roll” is the only single by late American rapper Big Pun from the album Endangered Species, which featured at time, R&B newcomer Ashanti on the chorus & outro. The video to the song was made into a cartoon and helped remember Big Pun throughout. The song peaked at number 53 on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Singles & Tracks and at number 16 on the Hot Rap Singles.

description.plain:
A spanish R&B song largely carried out by former Terror Squad member Tony Sunshine, with a verse from Big Pun.

Was made to be a vulgar humor song, dichotomously sung with smooth vocals.  It’s about fans who gave Pun insincere flattery because of his fame.

songs.title: Legendary Cypher
songs.title_with_featured: Legendary Cypher (Ft. Canibus, DMX, John Forté, Mic Geronimo & Yasiin Bey)

description.plain:
This cypher made sometime in the late 90s features some of hip-hop’s brightest talents from that era. Many of the verses in the cypher would be used in later songs including: DMX’s “Ain’t No Way”, Yasiin Bey/Mos Def’s “RE: DEFinition”, Big Pun’s “The Dream Shatterer”, and Canibus’s “Second Round K.O.”

This cypher went viral online when posted on YouTube in 2009 because of it being extremely rare to find at the time.

Fans have praised the cypher, and most notably Big Pun’s verse for its speed, flow, and delivery compared to its studio version.

songs.full_title: Mamma by Big Pun (Ft. Tony Sunshine)
songs.title: Mamma

description.plain:
On this song in the 2001 album, Endangered Species, Pun openly admits his weaknesses, his love for his hometown and mother.

Producer The Alchemist talked about his experience working with pun in an interview with Complex:


With the exception of Snoop, my best and most memorable experiences in the studio were with Big Pun. I have so many Pun stories. I was really lucky. We didn’t end up getting to release a lot, but the moments I had in the studio with him getting to work were…I can’t even…there are no words to describe Pun.

I didn’t have my weight up enough to really be creating the greatest amount of music with him but I remember his character. It’s really wack that he wasn’t able to make more of the music that he made because he was on his way to some other shit with the singing. Sometimes I go and watch old footage and interviews of him and he’s just, he was great, man.

songs.full_title: The Dream Shatterer (Original) by Big Pun
songs.title: The Dream Shatterer (Original)

description.plain:
This is not the version that appears on the Capital Punishment album. Although the original version, it didn’t see release until months after the remix, on an independent release from producer Buckwild.



The reason for exclusion from Capital Punishment is likely due to its use of a sample from Love Unlimited Orchestra. The same loop was used that year by Pras/Wyclef (“Ghetto Superstar”) and Noreaga/DJ Clue (“Thugs R Us”)

There is a widely-circulated video of a “freestyle cypher” featuring Big Pun and several other upwardly-mobile underground MCs circa 1998. The majority of Pun’s bars from that session (see below) would soon find their way into this song.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QEB7E1nCV6w&t=5m3s

songs.full_title: The Creation (Intro) by Big Pun
songs.title: The Creation (Intro)

description.plain:
The Creation (Intro) is the first track on the album. As the title suggests, track describes a fictional creation of Big Pun’s character, Punisher, interpolated from a classical book written in 1818 by Mary Shelley, Frankenstein.  In it, a character Dr. Frankenstein revives a dead body using electricity. The creature would later be known as Frankenstein’s Monster.

Big Pun compares his deadlyness and mightiness to the Monster, however in his origin story, his maker uses iconic and legendary black personalities as engreedients; such as Big Daddy Kane, Kool G Rap, Rakim, Eddie Murphy and Michael Jackson- only characters that probably greatly effected Pun’s carreer.
